Article.ArticleTitle: A comparison study of C19T (T = C, Cr, Ti, Fe, and Ni) nanocages by first-principle DFT calculation for removal of ozone-destroyer pollutants.

AbstractText: In the present work, the interaction of dichloromethane (CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>) and chloroform (CHCl<sub>3</sub>) on C<sub>20</sub> and C<sub>19</sub>T (T = Cr, Ti, Fe, Ni) has been studied by density functional theory (DFT). The results have been investigated by binding energy, net charge transfer, electrical and thermodynamic properties, and frontier orbitals. Although the complexes of CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub> and CHCl<sub>3</sub> on free C<sub>20</sub> nanocages showed slightly binding energy (- 0.029 and - 0.006 eV, respectively), doping of Cr, Ti, Fe, Ni transition metal atoms on C<sub>20</sub> nanocage improved the binding energy. The best binding energy was attributed to the adsorption of CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub> on C<sub>19</sub>Cr (- 0.755 eV). Based on ESP maps, doping of Cr, Ti, Fe, and Ni is the cause of strong electrophilic region creation which is very useful for adsorption process CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub> and CHCl<sub>3</sub> on nanocages. Also, natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis showed that the best charge transfer was 0.253 eV which was related to the formation of C<sub>19</sub>Fe-CHCl<sub>3</sub> complex. In addition, the least HOMO-LUMO energy gap between free nanocages (C<sub>20</sub>, C<sub>19</sub>Cr, C<sub>19</sub>Ti, C<sub>19</sub>Fe, and C<sub>19</sub>Ni) is 4.05 eV (C<sub>19</sub>Ti). The thermodynamic investigations indicated that due to the negative enthalpy, all of the studied adsorption processes were exothermic.
